conclusion: Set up the notation: m is the mass of each block (A and B), k is the spring constant (light, mass-less spring), F is the constant vertical upward force applied to A, x(t) is the extension of the spring (upward displacement of A relative to B), ω = √(k / m).
Initially, x = 0 and ẋ = 0 (the system is at rest).

premise: B is in contact with the ground, so the ground exerts a normal reaction N such that N + kx – mg = 0.
The moment B is just about to leave the ground is characterised by N = 0.

conclusion: Equation of motion of block A while B is still on the ground: During the interval from t = 0 until the instant B leaves the ground, B does not move, therefore its lower end of the spring is fixed to the ground.

premise: For A (upward positive): mẍ = F – mg – kx.
conclusion: Equation of motion: mẍ = F – mg – kx.

premise: Rewrite mẍ = F – mg – kx: ẍ + (k / m)x = (F – mg)/m ≡ C (constant).
conclusion: With ω = √(k/m), the solution is x(t) = (F – mg)/k [1 – cos ωt].
The constants are fixed by x(0)=0 and ẋ(0)=0.

premise: Apply the lift–off condition: B leaves the ground when kx = mg. Using x(t) = (F – mg)/k [1 – cos ωt].
conclusion: k x = k (F – mg)/k [1 – cos ωt] = (F – mg) [1 – cos ωt].
The minimum constant force that can satisfy this is obtained when [1 – cos ωt*] reaches its largest possible value, 2.

premise: Putting [1 – cos ωt*] = 2 gives 2 (F – mg) = mg.

conclusion: Thus the smallest constant pull that will just make B leave the floor is 1.5 mg.
Any larger force would also work, but the problem says “a constant force is applied … until B just leaves the ground”, i.e. the least force able to do so.
